This course is concerned with understanding how both individuals and firms assess and evaluate risk. The goal of this class is to provide a framework of tools to successfully manage risk and real-world frictions that limit the amount of risk sharing in the economy. Topics discussed during the semester can be broken down into three sections: the formal concept of risk, various methods for mitigating or eliminating risks faced by both individuals and corporations, and the examination of when firms do and do not have a motivation to manage risk.

The majority of students enjoyed this course and found it to be “dynamic” and “interesting.” Many students mentioned liking that the class was split up into three modules because it gave the class organization. Some commented that the course was very well split between qualitative and quantitative material.

Professor Smetters was described as “a wonderful professor.” He taught the third module, which covers the examination of when firms do and do not have a motivation to manage risk and investigates the role of the legal system in corporate risk management.

The grade for the course is based on equally weighted averages of three exams. There are no formal prerequisites for this course although it is recommended that students have an introductory knowledge of statistics, microeconomics, and finance (STAT101, BPUB 250, and FNCE100).
